body: cc @iyounus

For more information, see https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@systemml.incubator.apache.org/msg01723.html

Note: original I was going to base our Java style on the Google StyleGuide (https://github.com/google/styleguide), but its license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/) appears to be "weak copyleft" which probably is not compatible with the Apache license when including source code (see https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html).

Therefore, this style template is an export based on the current Eclipse standard format. It utilizes tab characters for indentation, as discussed on the mailing list.

There is a bug in scala logistic regression that needs to be fixed. Setting prediction to raw prediction might not fix the issue. Here is my recommendation to be consistent wrt this notebook:
1. Create a separate PR and delete this notebook.
2. Keep this PR open until the bug is fixed.
3. Once the bug is fixed, merge the notebook :)
LGTM. Thank you @bdwyer2! I'll merge.
LGTM. The only thing I'm not clear about is the stain_ref. These are hard coded numbers and its not very clear to me where these are coming from. Is it fixed for the whole analysis?
@mboehm7 Can this be merged in now?

Thanks, @iyounus.  Yeah the `stain_ref` and `max_sat_ref` are constants that represent the stain vectors (i.e. top 2 eigen vectors or SVD directions projected back into optical density space) and saturations (after solving for sats given the optical density values and the computed stain vecs) from a slide with a desired or ideal coloring.  Once they are found, they can be used for the whole dataset, and any given slide will be reconstructed from those ideal vectors.
It's just slow on the cluster, and doesn't always invoke an actual remote parfor.  I think it would be good to go ahead and merge this and use it as an example while we're pushing the engine forward.
LGTM :+1:

How does this fit into SystemML's execution model, which tries to ensure equivalent results (modulo rounding issues) across backends?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1484/
By default, we always use double precision which guarantees equivalent results. The user has to explicitly turn on single precision and hence is aware of loss of precision.
which would be ok, iff all backends and operations would support single precision accuracy.

Sorry, I disagree with the iff clause especially for an optional feature that is not turned on by default. If it helps, I plan to support lower precision for GPU backend once I get some free cycles.

See a partial integration for a subset of operations like that creates more problems than it solves. In the presence of rewrites and operator selection, it is not even clear to a user, at script level, which operations are affected. In addition, there are issues like converting inputs from double to float, which memory requirements are not capture by the memory estimates of the compiler. Finally, my major concern is that we only exploit low-hanging fruits like calling existing library functions without addressing the actual hard part of a full compiler and runtime integration for all operations. Supporting different matrix value types is great but requires a proper design and consistent integration.

I am having trouble using this on Linux. What are the minimum arguments I'd need to give it?
This is what I tried:
```
bin/systemml-spark-submit.py --master local matmult.dml
```

Error I got:
```
usage: systemml-spark-submit.py [--help] [--master] [--driver-memory]
                                [--num-executors] [--executor-memory]
                                [--executor-cores] [--conf  [...]] -nvargs
                                NVARGS [NVARGS ...] [-args  [...]] [-config]
                                [-stats STATS] [-explain] [-exec] -f
systemml-spark-submit.py: error: argument -nvargs is required
```

My `$SPARK_HOME` is set correctly.
matmult.dml:
```R
A = rand(rows=10, cols=1000)
B = rand(rows=1000, cols=10)
C = A%*% B

print(toString(C))
```

I second the idea of supporting different matrix types. Given the short runway and stiff competition, we should at least attempt to give users the flexibility to address temporary shortcomings until we come up with a full integration. This also helps validate the major effort required for full integration of a given feature.

Again, we should not stop optional features (turned off by default), meant for advanced users that provides significant performance benefits to a large class of deep learning problems (the field in which SystemML is not yet competitive). I am OK with flagging these features with necessary disclaimers in the documentation :)

Hello @nakul02 `'-nvargs', required=True` and `'-f', required=True` were compulsory arguments. 

Now this has been changed this to only `-f` being compulsory. Now please try again
`./systemml-spark-submit.py --master local -f matmul.dml`
This is good. What platforms other than mac have you tested this on?

Are you using maven2 ? If yes, can you please update to maven3: http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/engine-dev-guide

Having a different value for matrices seems like a better idea than this, as a holistic feature.
In the face of stiff competition, maybe quickly adding features, and consequently, technical debt is not a good idea.

However, if the benefits of this are large and made obvious by experiments on end-to-end DL use cases, I am ok with it. 
If this PR ends up getting merged, this need to either be implemented to completion or be yanked out completely. I am absolutely against having incomplete features for so-called advanced users and let future contributors deal with the technical debt.

@niketanpansare - do you have any experimental results (end-to-end DL) that you can post here?

Interesting to see that the im2col + OpenBLAS combo is actually faster for doubles than MKL-DNN.  Just shows that the focus is on single precision. üëç 

As for how to move forward, we know that we will need to support single precision (or even lower), especially on GPUs (modern models may not fit with double precision).  So, the conversation here needs to be on what are the concrete steps that would be needed for adding this to the engine in a timely manner.  As @niketanpansare has noted, we are up against some serious competition, so we really need to be focused.

One possibility here is to have an internal staged rollout of single precision in the engine, but externally present the option of either single or double precision to the user, without any specification of which ops/backends are affected.

EDIT: I posted this at the same time as @nakul02, but I also agree with @nakul02's view that we should make sure that we are minimizing any technical debt.  Basically, let's figure out how to do this, and then do it.

>> do you have any experimental results (end-to-end DL) that you can post here?

Here are the statistics for one of the parfor worker used in Mike's final prediction demo at strata:
```bash
Heavy hitter instructions (name, time, count):
-- 1) conv2d_bias_add 71633.031 sec 1201029
-- 2) ba+* 27327.518 sec 4832432
-- 3) + 27052.159 sec 2811118
-- 4) * 11866.432 sec 1201023
-- 5) / 11417.598 sec 1246365
-- 6) - 11406.372 sec 1269053
-- 7) sqrt 10791.259 sec 1202002
-- 8) sel+ 7915.427 sec 1065033
-- 9) rmvar 2576.081 sec 20220609
-- 10) leftIndex 1010.286 sec 45338
```

Please note the subset of heavy hitter for 3-5 could be either fused as batch-norm operation or using codegen, making the performance of `conv2d_bias_add` and `ba+*` even more critical.

Setup:
- Total number of nodes: 9
- Each node has Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2680 v3 @ 2.50GHz (48 vcores) and 100GB executor memory. The data is stored on HDFS is parquet format.
- Python script used in the current setup: https://github.com/niketanpansare/bc_weights/blob/master/scoring_rowwisecropping.py
- DML script called by the above Python script: https://github.com/niketanpansare/bc_weights/blob/master/resnet_prediction_parfor_rowwisecropping.dml
- We use im2col based implementation (which is also what Caffe, TensorFlow and other frameworks use) for conv2d_bias_add. We use MKL's dgemm for matrix multiplication in this operator. 

You can compare `conv2d_bias_add (71633.031 sec)`  to `openblas native.blas.datatype=double (34.881 seconds)` with greater than or equal to 32 channels. With `mkl dnn native.blas.datatype=float (10.765 seconds)`, this number should come down by 3.25x. You should see similar performance gains for `ba+*`.

>> I am absolutely against having incomplete features for so-called advanced users and let future contributors deal with the technical debt.

I think there has been a misunderstanding. The PR itself is complete: all it does is utilizes BLAS+MKL DNN more efficiently. @nakul02  Please let me know what specific part is bothering you.

Challenges with supporting multiple types:
- Multi-month project with no volunteer to take it on.
- API complexity: Either introduce generic types/algebra in DML or write `k` copies of nn layers. Highlighting Mike's slack comment: `max(0, X)` explodes, `max(0.0, X)` works just fine, and `max(X, 0)` works just fine as well.
- Implementation complexity: `n` times more operators to guarantee numerical stability (for example: if we are concerned with precision difference between sgemm and dgemm, then imagine the operation: float * double + int with kahan summation). 

Not supporting single-precision implies even a fair reviewer will always see a performance difference of 2-3x on CP (probably on GPU too). This difference is significant enough to shoo away deep learning users, where a typical training takes months.
@niketanpansare I am using maven3 :(. I am still not sure whats the root cause of this failure.

Although I have used the same Eclipse defaults for about 15 years, I just recently switched to removing trailing whitespace. Git/GitHub tend to flag trailing whitespace as an error and developers such as @dusenberrymw have convinced me that removing trailing whitespace tends to be a good practice to follow. I updated my Eclipse using:
```
Preferences --> Java --> Editor --> Save Actions --> Configure
Code Organizing --> Remove trailing whitespace (and All lines)
```

Thank you Arvind for addressing license early in development process.  Good catch removing opencsv-2.3.jar from list since no longer bundled in lib folder for current build.  Also good catch regarding newer protobuf.  However, new lines 247-250 could be confusing since they are detached from existing protobuf-java license text at lines 293-323.  Maybe just updating the protobuf-java version number from 2.5.0 to 3.2.0 at line 293 would be sufficient assuming the license text for version 3.2.0 hasn't changed.
